title.narrative: Mobile storage solutions at Humanitarian Hubs

description.narrative: The WFP-led Logistics Sector is supporting the relief efforts of the Government of Nigeria by augmenting the capacity for logistics coordination and logistics information management among humanitarian logistics actors and is facilitating access to, and implementation of key common services on behalf of the Humanitarian Community. Through maintaining a continuous presence in Borno State since August 2016, and constant liaison and consultation with the government agencies and humanitarian responders, the Logistics Sector has ensured that its support remains agile and fitted to the needs on the ground. Main activities: Coordination: to minimize duplication and gaps in logistics response efforts Information Management: to support operations and decision-making Service Provision - Temporary Storage: to supplement existing capacity Civil-Military Liaison and Access: to ensure regular and secure delivery of humanitarian cargo Training: to support local capacity strengthening Following a recommendation from the Inter-Sector Working Group and the Government of Nigeria, the Humanitarian Country Team determined the gradual establishment of Humanitarian Hubs in Borno State last year. These Hubs will provide a common base of operations for humanitarian actors present in the selected areas with critical enablers, including security, radio, internet, office space, accommodation, as well as logistics support and warehousing. These Hubs will provide a unified framework for coordinating overall response efforts. A ‘2017 Logistics Sector Strategy Workshop’ was held in Maiduguri on 12 November 2016, in which participants also identified the need for common storage sites outside Maiduguri. The identified locations where in alignment with the Humanitarian Hub locations, however not in the same order of priority. Progress made so far in terms of service provision – storage: The Logistics Sector is encouraging a common approach for storage in hard to reach areas outside Maiduguri through a variety of means including: implementation of Common Storage in coordination with Humanitarian Hubs as needed and as they come online establishment of dedicated Common Storage managed by Logistics Sector partners in locations, where Humanitarian Hubs are not yet established direct provision of equipment to augment the capacity of individual organisations were other options are either not necessary, or not feasible. To ensure readiness to implement any of the three options listed above (as appropriate to emerging needs and limitations) the Logistics Sector has acquired and dispatched critical logistics equipment (i.e. Mobile Storage/Warehousing Units [MSUs], generators, pallets, office containers) to support its partners, and will ensure sufficient materials are procured and in-country to meet emerging needs (i.e. equipment to support implementation of temperature-controlled storage, and additional common storage). To date, the Logistics Sector has identified NGO partners who will take on the management of the Logistics Sector common storage in Monguno (Solidarites International) and Banki (Intersos). As the Humanitarian Hub is being finalised in Ngala, the common storage is being established on the compound next to the IHP camp. Project readiness in all three location is expected by early July 2017. Planning to establish additional common storage locations is ongoing, in consultation with IOM as manager of the Humanitarian Hubs, humanitarian partners and the Government of Nigeria. After the rainy season, future common storage sites shall be aligned with the Humanitarian Hub sites.
